and the marked attention paid tO him on his arrival by Mir. Canning and other min isters, proved that those expectations were not unjuStly formed. An overrnling Prov idence, however, did not permit them to be realized. During his voyage Mir. King was attacked with disease often the con- sequence of a voyage, and which so im- paired his health, as to prevent him from an active discharge of the duties of his off, flee. After remaining abroad year, in hope of re-establiShing his health without any improvement, he determined to return to die in his native land, in the bosom of his family and his friends. Here, cheer ed by the attentions of an affectionate fam fly, and in a composed and resigned state, he calmly awaited his approaching end.

 It is when men like him are taken from among us we have cause for grief We remember the days of bis former useful ness, and bend in reverence before the christening stroke. We rejoice that he should so long have been spared-and that the blow descended not in the hour of his prime and his usefulness. In manner, MT. King was mild, and dgnifed-m temper firm and decided. As speaker, he was modle for parliamentary debate. His compatriots in the Senate, will long re- member the respect which he manifested for their opinions, whilst he firmly main tained his ewn. As statesman, prudent, penetrating and comprehensive in his views; his country vii long have cause for gratitude, that his talents were devoted to the promotion of public good. He was his country's true friend and while he did not hesitate to condemn the policy which placed us in collision with Great Britain, he did not permit his feelings to opperate, when his fortune and influence were required, to promote the successful termination of the war. His private char acter was without blemish. As a husband, affectionate and sincere-as a farther an object of veneration to his children, he has descended with lamentation to the tomb. As patriot his country monrus his loss.

the indians. They were formerly resident of Boston, and were taken captive near the Can ada line in the late war. Alter changing mas ters several times, they were taken by the FIat-Heads to the Rocky Mountains. They made several attempts to escape, during their captivity, but were re-taken and subjected to the most excrutiating tortures two of them had their tongues cut out to the roots; the third lost part of his, and can tell the tale of their sufferings in an indstiect manner. When they made their last fruitless attempt at es- cape they were 800 miles from the habtations of the whites. A squaw finally assisted them by conducting them about fifty miles through the wilderness, and placing them upon tract to the white settlements.

We declare, in sincerity, that from the known changes in public sentiment in Penn sylvania favorable to the Administration, there seems to us reasonable ground to hope that MT. Adams will be sustained by the people of this great, patriotic and intel ligent state. a.

 Let it be remembered that less than one quarter of the voters in the state gave their suffrages at the last election for the Jack son Ticket! Great changes have since taken place, favorable to the Administra- ton. We shall have mighty struggle--a great turn out of the People-the question will not be settled by politicians 1; and let not the Combination too confidently say, "Pennsylvania is eursr' r'-They reckon without their host. If the Administration continues to pursue a prudent and wise course, as is it is almost universally admit ted, by unprejudiced men, that they have
From the Village Record. A VOICE IN PENNSYLVANIA.

spent the Inst winter iD Cuba. in hopCS that the mild climate of that country might restore him to health, or at any rate alle-I viaie his disease; but on his return this spring it was soon perceived that he had not been benefited by the change, and that lis disease was too firmly fixed, to afford

 ny well founded hope of his recovery. He was concious of his approaching diso- iution, and met death with composure, and humble resignation to the Divine will.

 At Plymouth, on the 18th, ut. aged 73, Mrs. ELIzABETH, wife of MT. Elijah War ner, and formerly the widow of MT. Ard Melton of Waterbury. In this instance of mortality, there is much room for be- slowing encOmium on the dead. Possess sed of strength of intellect,a and mind cul- tivated far above the mediocrity, together with conspicuous piety, her society was truly interesting. She made every reas- onable exertion to contribute to the wants of the poor and needy, and was ever read- y to mingle with the afflicted the sympa- thetic tear. Her life was devoted to use- fulness: she gained many friends, and di- ed, after about three days sickness, prob ably without single enemy.

 MiJord, May 1st, 1927,

 JEHIEL WILLIAMS, Esq. Judge. : PON the Petition of RUFUS FULLER ~ of Kent in said district, showing to this Court that heis the Parent and natural Guar dian of Linus F. Fuller, Julia Ann Fuller and Rufus Fuller, Jun. all of said Kent. minors. under the age of twenty y-one years, that said minors own and possess in fee-simple as ten- ants in common about twenty y-taree acres of land situated in the north part of the town of Plymouth in Litchfeld county, which came to said minors by descent from their late moth CT Bede Fuller, deceased, and. their grand mother Mehitabe Fem, deceased, and of about the value of seven hundred and fifty dollars-praying for reasons in said petition set forth that an order might be passed au- thorising and empowering said Petitioner or some other suitable person to sell and convey said premises according to the statute in such case made and provided. As per Petition on file dated May 1st 1927.

 Ordered that said Petition be continued t8 the 18th day of July 1927, at 12 o'clock at noon, at the Probate Office in New Milford, when and where said Petitioner may be heard on the merits of his said Petition. And that notice of the pendency thereof be given by publishing this Order in a Newspaper printed at Litchfeld weeks successively at least weeks previous to said 18th day of July 1927.

 Atrue Copy of Record,

 AZ Test, NATHANIEL PERRY CLrk

Notice to Revolutionary Pensioners.

 Instructions have been received at the Pension Office in this city, from the War De pertinent, which require new forms for pow CTS of attorney and paths of indentifcation, in order to receive the semi-annaai stipend which will become due the 4th day of Sept. next. The alteration is required for the pur- pose of having a uniformity in those docu- ments from the several pension offices in the United States.

 Pension Office, Boston, April 16, 1827." l3T7Such blank powers of attorney, Sc. as

 are required, may be had at the "Litch-

 field Bookstore in season for the next se-

 mi-annual payment in September.

 One or two city editors affect to think that the dignity of the state is greatly seandalized by the course pursued by Gov. To,niinson, in going directly on to Hartford at the opening of the session instead of staying at home un- til waited upon, and informed of his election course would have displayed some false mod esty, as well as have been an useless waste of time and money. The canyassess appointed by law had declared him elected, and it would have been maiden timidty in him, had he neglected to have gone directly on to Hart ford, where his presence was absolutely nc cessary for the commencement of legislative business; more especially since such course was urged upon him by Gov. Wolcott, whose health would not permit him to go to Hart ford. If the independent and honorable course he pursued be departure from ancient usages, as the Herald asserts, we will only say that it is high time such nsages were done away, and that the encroachment upon them had better be made this spring than next, or at any other time hereafter.-If no other argu- mcnts can be produced against Gov. T. he will receive the unqualified support and ap probation of the citizens of Connecticut for many years to come.

 Mr Mdcon-This gentleman, who has been so long in public service as representative and senator in Congress, has been invited by some of the citizens of North Carolina to partake of public dinner. In reply to the invitation MT Macon says ;-" Permit me to say to you that have never been to public dinner giv ,en to any man for public services, and that do not approve of them." Whatever may be said infaavor ofpublic dinners, as to their ten dency to promote harmony and good feeling, they have of late been perverted to scenes of rancor and bitter enmity; and in stead of that generous flow of liberal feelings which ought to characterize such feasts, every ef- fort has been made to excite jealousy and ill., will against the greatest and best men in the country. No wonder the, venerable Macon, after having read the hostile sentiments re- gently delivered at opposition dinners at the south, should declare that he does not ap- prove of them. No honest man can approve efsuch scenes of turmoil and strife.

delivered by M. Minziacky to the Refs Ef- fendi, the following phrase, which is con- sidered as authentic, is particularly spoken of :-'The' Porte itself must desire an in- tervention. If the Greeks are conqerors it becomes necessary, and in the contra ry case the Porte would deceive itself if it believed that the Emperor Nicholas would see with indifference tho >extermin- ation of people protesting the same re- ligion as himself ''-Augsburg Gazette.

 Madrid, March LA decree of Feb ruary l2, gives new proof of the zeal of the Spanish Government in hastening the organization of the Royalist volunteers 1; ordering the Intendants of Provinces, on pain of being suspended from their offices, to hasten the levy of the taxes imposed by the decree of the 24th of August for the equipment of those troops.

 "Paris, March 12.-Letters from St. Petersburgh say, that differences have aris- en between Generals Yermaloff and Paske- witsch, relative to the employment of the Russian troops in Georgia under their com mand. General Diebitsch, Aid-de-camp to the Emperor, is gone for the purpose of reconciling them.-Augsburg Gazette.

 The morning papers of Friday contain no news. The Quotidienne says, that the news fir pm Galica, received at Madrid, is favorable to the Portuguese royalists, and the Constitutional, that the preparations for war are continued in Spain with much activity"

 From the London Times

 We copy from Dublin paper the fol- lowing extraordinary paragraph ;- 'sDnbtin, March k2.-Friday, after the arrival cf the packet bringing the defeat ''of the Ga. .holic question in the House of sCommops orders were sent to the Pi- s'geon-housc, to forward 5,OOO,O00 rounds ''of musket ball-cartridges to the different "garrisons throughout the country" "--FTec- m0n'S Journal

 Here, then, is the cementary on that text which the Orangemen have delivered to Parliament for the guidence of its poli- cy towards the Irish nation. Men demand their rights, and the answer is five millions of leaden bullets Almost ball-caf tr'dge apiece for the Catholics of Ireland. God help them.

  we find tine subjoining intelligence, accor- ding to which it will be seen that determ- ined efforts are to be made on the part of Russia, in behalf of the Greeks.

 Constantioople Feb. IT.

 M. Won Minziacky, without waiting for the arrival of the Russian Ambassador, the Marquis de Ribeaupiere, has presented very energetic note relative to the pacifi- cation of Greece, which is said to contain the following remarkable passage: "The sublime Porte itself must desire an inter- vcntion, for if the Greeks should prove conquerers, they would also, in all proba- bility, seek an intervention, and if the Greeks should be subdued, the Porte should not indulge in the delusion, that the Elm peror Nicholas would remain an inactive spectator of the massacre of his fellow be- lieyers."

 This remarkable declaration, the au- thenticity of which is affirmed on most re- spectable authority, has caused an extraor- dinary sensation here, and people are very curious to see how the Divan will act after the arrival of M. de Ribeaupiere; it is we'll known, that the Refs Efendi had, prievously, replied to the confidential ver- bal overtures of Mir. s. Canning and M. Minziackny on this subject, that the Porte would not accept of an intervention. ' The London Courier of the 17th of March says

 The Algemeine Zetung, which we have received this morning to the 1lth inst. con- tains an article dated Trieste, March 2d, which states, on the authority of letter from Corfu, of the 18th ult. that the Greeks had possessed themselves of Mis- silonghi.

 Irish Catholics.-" Upon two things, we recollect, that all Catholics in this part of Ireland are nearly unaminous-the ex- pediency of making direct appeal to the Royal lllustrious Parsonage who pronoun- ced the "parting injunction" so feelingly alluded to by Sir Francis Burdett, and of forwading another series of petitions, con- tradictory of the hell-born faishoods, if of nothing else, upon which we are to supp pose that the decision of Tuesday night was partly founded. As to the provinces, they will not, we presume, be slow in indi- eating their opinion as to what is proper to be done in the present unhappy state of our affairs. ."- Dublin paper.

 OLD POT TTICAT pARTIES
FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE.

In New-Haven on the evening of the 3Oth ult. MT. JOHN J. BARNARD, Cashier of the Mechanics Bank, aged S1. Mr. B. was native of Hartford, but has resided in this city for several years. At the or ganization of the Norwalk Bank he was appointed cashier of that institution, and continued in that office till the establish- ment of the Mechanics bank in this city, when he was offered, and accepted the of flee of cashier in the latter institution. He was a gentlman of very handsome talents, and was highly and deservedly respected by all who became acquainted with him. By his constant and devoted attention to business, he laid the foundation for rapid decline, which has at length removed him from his family and friends, in the prime of life, and in the midst of usefulness. He

SPRAYED

draw the old party lines in reference to the present Administration and the presses in that interest affect an amusing exclusive ness to the claim of being the organs of the old republican party. To show the talsity of this assertion, tho fact has been stated that but one man of the old Feder- al party, Mir. Mills, of Massachusetts, is attached to the Administration in the Sem ate, while it is notorious, that Messrs. Tazewell, Berrien, Rowan, Ridgely, Me Lane, and we believe some others, are the principal leaders of the Opposition in the Senate, every one of whom were identi- fled with the federal party during the ad ministration of Jefferson and Madison. The Leading paper of the Opposition, the Washington Telegraph, is rather puzzled at this state of the case, and to help the matter has got up list of the members of the Senate, friendly to the Administration, who, according to its story, are of the true Hortford Contention stamp! Our readers will be much amused to learn that this for midahle list is thus made out. After nam- ing Mir. Mills, the Telegraph says-"We now add to that list" Ia list, by the way having but one name upon it) "Mr. Har- rison, of Ohio, MT. Noble, of Indiana, MT. ROBBINS, of Rhode Island, and Clay ton, of Delaware. All of thase are the 1 advocates of MT. Adams, and although they were not all as much identified with the Hartford Convention as Mir. Mills, the editors of the Intelligencer know that they are federalists."

 As to Mir. Harrison, ever body knows he was appointed governor of the North Western Territory by MT. Jefferson, and Noble has represented Indiana Ia repub- lican state) in the Senate ever since she was admitted iuto the Union. MT. Clay ton undoubtedly ranked as federalist, but he is no longer in the Senate.

 As to "Mr. Roddins of Rhode Island" he has been leader republican in this state, since the first administration of Mir. Jefferson, and has repeatedly been supp ported by that party as a candidate for state offices. We commend to the perusal of the Editor of the Telegraph pamph- let written by Mir. Robbins in 1911, de- lending the policy of MT. Madison.

 It is, in our estimation, perfectly ridi- ulous to attempt to revive these forgotten distinctions between parties that no longer exist. We rejoice to find that the present Administration is supported by the liber- al men of both the old parties, and that the true distinction now is honesty, capablity, faithfulnes to the Constitution, without reference to the badges of party. This it is that the opposition dread so much. They act purely as politcial -partizans and mercinaries, and he among them who has no honest claim to reward for his services, can look for reward only under leader who is pledged to elevate his own parti- zans merely because they are such. We should not have noticed this wild statement of the Telegraph, but for the purpose of correcting so gross perversion of fact

 If this be specimen of the truth that pre- vails in the colums of that paper, its dis cipleS must be in most alarming state of ignorance-Prov. Amer.

 Letter from Jack Tar to his Uncle Sam. DEAR UNcLE-I have made number of voyages in your good ship Union, and l admire her accommodations, her sailing, and the good order which has usually prevailed on board but from what have lately overheard, I" understand that some part of our crew are clamouring for a change of officers, which if effected may produce trouble. IL appears that their de- sign is to turn out tie present Pilot out of his birth, and make pilot of the Gunner, who is as bold man as ever pointed can- non, but boldness is not the qualification for which pilot is most valued. and l hope you will excuse me, Uncle, if say that in the characteristic of Pilot, that aI ounce of circumspection is of more wortf than pound of boldness, if they could be both weighed. Your pilot has long studi- ed to make himself acquainted with the native shoals, and with foreign straits, and his attention is so devoted to the Chart an d Compass, that when I turn in at night, I feel as safe, as if was landed on Terra- Firma. Since I have been on board the Union, her guns have rairly been fired ex- cept for rejoicing, and I hope they never will be heard for any other purpose, but if your Gunner should be showed into the Pilots place, his fondness for the cannon's sound, may possibly lead him to indulge his favorite amusement, at the hazard of the ships Company. My fears have led me to make these remarks, which l hope you will excuse from Your respect

done, the people will sustain them. Now our course will be an open and frank oue. We shall support Mir. Adams, when right, against the Southern combination to nut him down, "right or wrOng." We will sustain him to the extent of our humble ef- forts, while he makes the good of his couu. try his polar star, notwithstanding the vic fence of the assaults against him. We openly and earnestly recommend to the friends of the Administration, in all parts Of the state, to come out early, boldly, de- cidedly-and that means should be taken. open and above board, to ascertain the public sentiment, to awaken public atten- tlon, and to present the various important questions at issue, fairly to the public mind. Let not the pOIitici0ns get the staft of the people. Let the peOpLe come out and act. Let the voice ofthe people be heard, and we confidently believe that at sciU De soeU A gentleman who has discovered mode of dressing flax without rotting, and who has an establishment in successful opera ton on the Hudson river, has agreed, if the produce of 200 acres of flax land can be secured to him, to locate himself in Es- sex or Middiesex county, where he will give $15 per ton for flax from the field, af- ter the seed is taken off, without any other preparation. 1t is calculated that at this price nett profit of from l2 to Is dollars per acre may be realized from the land while the farmer will be freed from the trouble of rotting, dressing, &c. and yet the gentleman proposes to sell his dressed flax cheaper by 20 per cent. than others who first rot, and then dress it. Besides, the flax that is dressed without rotting, is much stronger, loses less in the manu- facture, is frmer, and softer.

 CatskiN Rec.

 Abolition of tSlaUery.-The law for the ab- olition of slavery in the state of New York, coming into force on the 4th July ensuing, ] meeting of the descendants of Africans has been held in Albany, where, on motion of Rev. MT. Paul, resolve passed to express the gra- titude of the Africans to Almighty God, by a public celebration. But as the ,chites cee- ] brate their independence on the 4th, the Afri- cans have chosen the 5th. a>

 1 A society to aid the abolition of African slavery, has been formed in SmithfeId, Ohio. Within about three weeks, accounts have been received at the office of the Genius of Universal Emancipation, of the formation of twelve new associations, upon the plan of the Ant-Slavery society of Maryland.

 That part of the odious law of Maryland which authorizes the immediate sale, out of the state, of coloured persons convicted of petty criminal offences, has to the honour of the legislature, been repealed.

 The editors of the Georgia Journal, in reply to the complaint of some subscriber, who had received his paper irregularly, make the fol- lowing sensible remark:

 :" If by the happening of some accident to the mail, our newspapers should fail but once l of reaching their destination, we soon hear of the complaints of subscribers. They are dis satisfied, and have reason to be so. From this they should learn to appreciate the dis { our subscription becomes due, and they fail to send it to us. If the failure of a newspa- per one week is matter of so much annoy ance to subscribers how much more reason have we to complain when there is failure week after week, and month after month, in the receipt of what is justly due us for our time and labour, expended for the amuse- ment and instruction of others"

 .WoOllfolk, the noted slave-dealer, has been fined for violent assault on B. Lun- dy, editor of the Genius of U Emancipa- ton. The chief justice, however, showed his disposition to punish the innocent, if he had the power. He said "he had never seen case in which the provocation for a battery was greater than the present-that if abusive language could ever be a justi6ca- tion for battery, this was that case-that ' the traverser was engaged in trade sanctioned by the laws of Maryland, and that Lundy had no right to reproach hin in such abusive language for carrying on lawful trade-that the trade itself was ben efcial to the state, as it removed great many rogues and vagabonds who were a nuisance in the state-that Lundy had re- 1 ceived no more than nerited reinstatement for his abuse of the traverser, and but for strict letter of the law, the Court would not fine Woollfolk any thing. The court however was obliged to fine him something, and they fined him one dollar and costs !'' pRTEn

VNHE subscriber has a general assortment A of well made GARNET FURNI- TURF at his ware house few rods east of Goodwin & Galpn's store, which he is selling very low for Cash or most kinds of produce and lumber.

 N. B.--Orders thankfully received and strictly attended to. Cash pad for good sea soned lumber of the following description, if delivered soon; butternut, or whitewood boards inch thick, soft maple 8 1-2 inches square, curl maple 3 l-2 or inches square. For sale, good one horse Wagon and Harness.

 ANDREW CHAPIN, late of Wolcott, county of Wayne and State ofNewYork, deceased, represented insolvent, when and where all persons interested may appear and be heard.

and the marked attention paid tO him on his arrival by Mir. Canning and other min isters, proved that those expectations were not unjuStly formed. An overrnling Prov idence, however, did not permit them to be realized. During his voyage Mir. King was attacked with disease often the con- sequence of a voyage, and which so im- paired his health, as to prevent him from an active discharge of the duties of his off, flee. After remaining abroad year, in hope of re-establiShing his health without any improvement, he determined to return to die in his native land, in the bosom of his family and his friends. Here, cheer ed by the attentions of an affectionate fam fly, and in a composed and resigned state, he calmly awaited his approaching end.

 It is when men like him are taken from among us we have cause for grief We remember the days of bis former useful ness, and bend in reverence before the christening stroke. We rejoice that he should so long have been spared-and that the blow descended not in the hour of his prime and his usefulness. In manner, MT. King was mild, and dgnifed-m temper firm and decided. As speaker, he was modle for parliamentary debate. His compatriots in the Senate, will long re- member the respect which he manifested for their opinions, whilst he firmly main tained his ewn. As statesman, prudent, penetrating and comprehensive in his views; his country vii long have cause for gratitude, that his talents were devoted to the promotion of public good. He was his country's true friend and while he did not hesitate to condemn the policy which placed us in collision with Great Britain, he did not permit his feelings to opperate, when his fortune and influence were required, to promote the successful termination of the war. His private char acter was without blemish. As a husband, affectionate and sincere-as a farther an object of veneration to his children, he has descended with lamentation to the tomb. As patriot his country monrus his loss.

We declare, in sincerity, that from the known changes in public sentiment in Penn sylvania favorable to the Administration, there seems to us reasonable ground to hope that MT. Adams will be sustained by the people of this great, patriotic and intel ligent state. a.

spent the Inst winter iD Cuba. in hopCS that the mild climate of that country might restore him to health, or at any rate alle-I viaie his disease; but on his return this spring it was soon perceived that he had not been benefited by the change, and that lis disease was too firmly fixed, to afford

 ny well founded hope of his recovery. He was concious of his approaching diso- iution, and met death with composure, and humble resignation to the Divine will.

 At Plymouth, on the 18th, ut. aged 73, Mrs. ELIzABETH, wife of MT. Elijah War ner, and formerly the widow of MT. Ard Melton of Waterbury. In this instance of mortality, there is much room for be- slowing encOmium on the dead. Possess sed of strength of intellect,a and mind cul- tivated far above the mediocrity, together with conspicuous piety, her society was truly interesting. She made every reas- onable exertion to contribute to the wants of the poor and needy, and was ever read- y to mingle with the afflicted the sympa- thetic tear. Her life was devoted to use- fulness: she gained many friends, and di- ed, after about three days sickness, prob ably without single enemy.

 In this town, at the poor house, Ceasar Barbary coloTTed man, aged 70.

At e Court of Probate held at Ne,c- Mil-

 ford, acithm and for the district cf Nev-

 MiJord, May 1st, 1927,

 JEHIEL WILLIAMS, Esq. Judge. : PON the Petition of RUFUS FULLER ~ of Kent in said district, showing to this Court that heis the Parent and natural Guar dian of Linus F. Fuller, Julia Ann Fuller and Rufus Fuller, Jun. all of said Kent. minors. under the age of twenty y-one years, that said minors own and possess in fee-simple as ten- ants in common about twenty y-taree acres of land situated in the north part of the town of Plymouth in Litchfeld county, which came to said minors by descent from their late moth CT Bede Fuller, deceased, and. their grand mother Mehitabe Fem, deceased, and of about the value of seven hundred and fifty dollars-praying for reasons in said petition set forth that an order might be passed au- thorising and empowering said Petitioner or some other suitable person to sell and convey said premises according to the statute in such case made and provided. As per Petition on file dated May 1st 1927.

 Ordered that said Petition be continued t8 the 18th day of July 1927, at 12 o'clock at noon, at the Probate Office in New Milford, when and where said Petitioner may be heard on the merits of his said Petition. And that notice of the pendency thereof be given by publishing this Order in a Newspaper printed at Litchfeld weeks successively at least weeks previous to said 18th day of July 1927.

 Atrue Copy of Record,

 AZ Test, NATHANIEL PERRY CLrk

Notice to Revolutionary Pensioners.

 Instructions have been received at the Pension Office in this city, from the War De pertinent, which require new forms for pow CTS of attorney and paths of indentifcation, in order to receive the semi-annaai stipend which will become due the 4th day of Sept. next. The alteration is required for the pur- pose of having a uniformity in those docu- ments from the several pension offices in the United States.

 Pension Office, Boston, April 16, 1827." l3T7Such blank powers of attorney, Sc. as

 are required, may be had at the "Litch-

 field Bookstore in season for the next se-

 mi-annual payment in September.

 One or two city editors affect to think that the dignity of the state is greatly seandalized by the course pursued by Gov. To,niinson, in going directly on to Hartford at the opening of the session instead of staying at home un- til waited upon, and informed of his election course would have displayed some false mod esty, as well as have been an useless waste of time and money. The canyassess appointed by law had declared him elected, and it would have been maiden timidty in him, had he neglected to have gone directly on to Hart ford, where his presence was absolutely nc cessary for the commencement of legislative business; more especially since such course was urged upon him by Gov. Wolcott, whose health would not permit him to go to Hart ford. If the independent and honorable course he pursued be departure from ancient usages, as the Herald asserts, we will only say that it is high time such nsages were done away, and that the encroachment upon them had better be made this spring than next, or at any other time hereafter.-If no other argu- mcnts can be produced against Gov. T. he will receive the unqualified support and ap probation of the citizens of Connecticut for many years to come.

 Mr Mdcon-This gentleman, who has been so long in public service as representative and senator in Congress, has been invited by some of the citizens of North Carolina to partake of public dinner. In reply to the invitation MT Macon says ;-" Permit me to say to you that have never been to public dinner giv ,en to any man for public services, and that do not approve of them." Whatever may be said infaavor ofpublic dinners, as to their ten dency to promote harmony and good feeling, they have of late been perverted to scenes of rancor and bitter enmity; and in stead of that generous flow of liberal feelings which ought to characterize such feasts, every ef- fort has been made to excite jealousy and ill., will against the greatest and best men in the country. No wonder the, venerable Macon, after having read the hostile sentiments re- gently delivered at opposition dinners at the south, should declare that he does not ap- prove of them. No honest man can approve efsuch scenes of turmoil and strife.

full articles.headline: FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE.
full articles.article:
delivered by M. Minziacky to the Refs Ef- fendi, the following phrase, which is con- sidered as authentic, is particularly spoken of :-'The' Porte itself must desire an in- tervention. If the Greeks are conqerors it becomes necessary, and in the contra ry case the Porte would deceive itself if it believed that the Emperor Nicholas would see with indifference tho >extermin- ation of people protesting the same re- ligion as himself ''-Augsburg Gazette.

 Madrid, March LA decree of Feb ruary l2, gives new proof of the zeal of the Spanish Government in hastening the organization of the Royalist volunteers 1; ordering the Intendants of Provinces, on pain of being suspended from their offices, to hasten the levy of the taxes imposed by the decree of the 24th of August for the equipment of those troops.

 "Paris, March 12.-Letters from St. Petersburgh say, that differences have aris- en between Generals Yermaloff and Paske- witsch, relative to the employment of the Russian troops in Georgia under their com mand. General Diebitsch, Aid-de-camp to the Emperor, is gone for the purpose of reconciling them.-Augsburg Gazette.

 The morning papers of Friday contain no news. The Quotidienne says, that the news fir pm Galica, received at Madrid, is favorable to the Portuguese royalists, and the Constitutional, that the preparations for war are continued in Spain with much activity"

 From the London Times

 We copy from Dublin paper the fol- lowing extraordinary paragraph ;- 'sDnbtin, March k2.-Friday, after the arrival cf the packet bringing the defeat ''of the Ga. .holic question in the House of sCommops orders were sent to the Pi- s'geon-housc, to forward 5,OOO,O00 rounds ''of musket ball-cartridges to the different "garrisons throughout the country" "--FTec- m0n'S Journal

 Here, then, is the cementary on that text which the Orangemen have delivered to Parliament for the guidence of its poli- cy towards the Irish nation. Men demand their rights, and the answer is five millions of leaden bullets Almost ball-caf tr'dge apiece for the Catholics of Ireland. God help them.

  we find tine subjoining intelligence, accor- ding to which it will be seen that determ- ined efforts are to be made on the part of Russia, in behalf of the Greeks.

 Constantioople Feb. IT.

 M. Won Minziacky, without waiting for the arrival of the Russian Ambassador, the Marquis de Ribeaupiere, has presented very energetic note relative to the pacifi- cation of Greece, which is said to contain the following remarkable passage: "The sublime Porte itself must desire an inter- vcntion, for if the Greeks should prove conquerers, they would also, in all proba- bility, seek an intervention, and if the Greeks should be subdued, the Porte should not indulge in the delusion, that the Elm peror Nicholas would remain an inactive spectator of the massacre of his fellow be- lieyers."

 This remarkable declaration, the au- thenticity of which is affirmed on most re- spectable authority, has caused an extraor- dinary sensation here, and people are very curious to see how the Divan will act after the arrival of M. de Ribeaupiere; it is we'll known, that the Refs Efendi had, prievously, replied to the confidential ver- bal overtures of Mir. s. Canning and M. Minziackny on this subject, that the Porte would not accept of an intervention. ' The London Courier of the 17th of March says

 The Algemeine Zetung, which we have received this morning to the 1lth inst. con- tains an article dated Trieste, March 2d, which states, on the authority of letter from Corfu, of the 18th ult. that the Greeks had possessed themselves of Mis- silonghi.

 Irish Catholics.-" Upon two things, we recollect, that all Catholics in this part of Ireland are nearly unaminous-the ex- pediency of making direct appeal to the Royal lllustrious Parsonage who pronoun- ced the "parting injunction" so feelingly alluded to by Sir Francis Burdett, and of forwading another series of petitions, con- tradictory of the hell-born faishoods, if of nothing else, upon which we are to supp pose that the decision of Tuesday night was partly founded. As to the provinces, they will not, we presume, be slow in indi- eating their opinion as to what is proper to be done in the present unhappy state of our affairs. ."- Dublin paper.

 OLD POT TTICAT pARTIES

full articles.headline: DIED,
full articles.article: In New-Haven on the evening of the 3Oth ult. MT. JOHN J. BARNARD, Cashier of the Mechanics Bank, aged S1. Mr. B. was native of Hartford, but has resided in this city for several years. At the or ganization of the Norwalk Bank he was appointed cashier of that institution, and continued in that office till the establish- ment of the Mechanics bank in this city, when he was offered, and accepted the of flee of cashier in the latter institution. He was a gentlman of very handsome talents, and was highly and deservedly respected by all who became acquainted with him. By his constant and devoted attention to business, he laid the foundation for rapid decline, which has at length removed him from his family and friends, in the prime of life, and in the midst of usefulness. He

 Litchfeld, Milton Soc.) May 8. 4.

draw the old party lines in reference to the present Administration and the presses in that interest affect an amusing exclusive ness to the claim of being the organs of the old republican party. To show the talsity of this assertion, tho fact has been stated that but one man of the old Feder- al party, Mir. Mills, of Massachusetts, is attached to the Administration in the Sem ate, while it is notorious, that Messrs. Tazewell, Berrien, Rowan, Ridgely, Me Lane, and we believe some others, are the principal leaders of the Opposition in the Senate, every one of whom were identi- fled with the federal party during the ad ministration of Jefferson and Madison. The Leading paper of the Opposition, the Washington Telegraph, is rather puzzled at this state of the case, and to help the matter has got up list of the members of the Senate, friendly to the Administration, who, according to its story, are of the true Hortford Contention stamp! Our readers will be much amused to learn that this for midahle list is thus made out. After nam- ing Mir. Mills, the Telegraph says-"We now add to that list" Ia list, by the way having but one name upon it) "Mr. Har- rison, of Ohio, MT. Noble, of Indiana, MT. ROBBINS, of Rhode Island, and Clay ton, of Delaware. All of thase are the 1 advocates of MT. Adams, and although they were not all as much identified with the Hartford Convention as Mir. Mills, the editors of the Intelligencer know that they are federalists."

 As to Mir. Harrison, ever body knows he was appointed governor of the North Western Territory by MT. Jefferson, and Noble has represented Indiana Ia repub- lican state) in the Senate ever since she was admitted iuto the Union. MT. Clay ton undoubtedly ranked as federalist, but he is no longer in the Senate.

 As to "Mr. Roddins of Rhode Island" he has been leader republican in this state, since the first administration of Mir. Jefferson, and has repeatedly been supp ported by that party as a candidate for state offices. We commend to the perusal of the Editor of the Telegraph pamph- let written by Mir. Robbins in 1911, de- lending the policy of MT. Madison.

 It is, in our estimation, perfectly ridi- ulous to attempt to revive these forgotten distinctions between parties that no longer exist. We rejoice to find that the present Administration is supported by the liber- al men of both the old parties, and that the true distinction now is honesty, capablity, faithfulnes to the Constitution, without reference to the badges of party. This it is that the opposition dread so much. They act purely as politcial -partizans and mercinaries, and he among them who has no honest claim to reward for his services, can look for reward only under leader who is pledged to elevate his own parti- zans merely because they are such. We should not have noticed this wild statement of the Telegraph, but for the purpose of correcting so gross perversion of fact

 If this be specimen of the truth that pre- vails in the colums of that paper, its dis cipleS must be in most alarming state of ignorance-Prov. Amer.

 Letter from Jack Tar to his Uncle Sam. DEAR UNcLE-I have made number of voyages in your good ship Union, and l admire her accommodations, her sailing, and the good order which has usually prevailed on board but from what have lately overheard, I" understand that some part of our crew are clamouring for a change of officers, which if effected may produce trouble. IL appears that their de- sign is to turn out tie present Pilot out of his birth, and make pilot of the Gunner, who is as bold man as ever pointed can- non, but boldness is not the qualification for which pilot is most valued. and l hope you will excuse me, Uncle, if say that in the characteristic of Pilot, that aI ounce of circumspection is of more wortf than pound of boldness, if they could be both weighed. Your pilot has long studi- ed to make himself acquainted with the native shoals, and with foreign straits, and his attention is so devoted to the Chart an d Compass, that when I turn in at night, I feel as safe, as if was landed on Terra- Firma. Since I have been on board the Union, her guns have rairly been fired ex- cept for rejoicing, and I hope they never will be heard for any other purpose, but if your Gunner should be showed into the Pilots place, his fondness for the cannon's sound, may possibly lead him to indulge his favorite amusement, at the hazard of the ships Company. My fears have led me to make these remarks, which l hope you will excuse from Your respect

done, the people will sustain them. Now our course will be an open and frank oue. We shall support Mir. Adams, when right, against the Southern combination to nut him down, "right or wrOng." We will sustain him to the extent of our humble ef- forts, while he makes the good of his couu. try his polar star, notwithstanding the vic fence of the assaults against him. We openly and earnestly recommend to the friends of the Administration, in all parts Of the state, to come out early, boldly, de- cidedly-and that means should be taken. open and above board, to ascertain the public sentiment, to awaken public atten- tlon, and to present the various important questions at issue, fairly to the public mind. Let not the pOIitici0ns get the staft of the people. Let the peOpLe come out and act. Let the voice ofthe people be heard, and we confidently believe that at sciU De soeU A gentleman who has discovered mode of dressing flax without rotting, and who has an establishment in successful opera ton on the Hudson river, has agreed, if the produce of 200 acres of flax land can be secured to him, to locate himself in Es- sex or Middiesex county, where he will give $15 per ton for flax from the field, af- ter the seed is taken off, without any other preparation. 1t is calculated that at this price nett profit of from l2 to Is dollars per acre may be realized from the land while the farmer will be freed from the trouble of rotting, dressing, &c. and yet the gentleman proposes to sell his dressed flax cheaper by 20 per cent. than others who first rot, and then dress it. Besides, the flax that is dressed without rotting, is much stronger, loses less in the manu- facture, is frmer, and softer.

 CatskiN Rec.

 Abolition of tSlaUery.-The law for the ab- olition of slavery in the state of New York, coming into force on the 4th July ensuing, ] meeting of the descendants of Africans has been held in Albany, where, on motion of Rev. MT. Paul, resolve passed to express the gra- titude of the Africans to Almighty God, by a public celebration. But as the ,chites cee- ] brate their independence on the 4th, the Afri- cans have chosen the 5th. a>

 1 A society to aid the abolition of African slavery, has been formed in SmithfeId, Ohio. Within about three weeks, accounts have been received at the office of the Genius of Universal Emancipation, of the formation of twelve new associations, upon the plan of the Ant-Slavery society of Maryland.

 That part of the odious law of Maryland which authorizes the immediate sale, out of the state, of coloured persons convicted of petty criminal offences, has to the honour of the legislature, been repealed.

 The editors of the Georgia Journal, in reply to the complaint of some subscriber, who had received his paper irregularly, make the fol- lowing sensible remark:

 :" If by the happening of some accident to the mail, our newspapers should fail but once l of reaching their destination, we soon hear of the complaints of subscribers. They are dis satisfied, and have reason to be so. From this they should learn to appreciate the dis { our subscription becomes due, and they fail to send it to us. If the failure of a newspa- per one week is matter of so much annoy ance to subscribers how much more reason have we to complain when there is failure week after week, and month after month, in the receipt of what is justly due us for our time and labour, expended for the amuse- ment and instruction of others"

 .WoOllfolk, the noted slave-dealer, has been fined for violent assault on B. Lun- dy, editor of the Genius of U Emancipa- ton. The chief justice, however, showed his disposition to punish the innocent, if he had the power. He said "he had never seen case in which the provocation for a battery was greater than the present-that if abusive language could ever be a justi6ca- tion for battery, this was that case-that ' the traverser was engaged in trade sanctioned by the laws of Maryland, and that Lundy had no right to reproach hin in such abusive language for carrying on lawful trade-that the trade itself was ben efcial to the state, as it removed great many rogues and vagabonds who were a nuisance in the state-that Lundy had re- 1 ceived no more than nerited reinstatement for his abuse of the traverser, and but for strict letter of the law, the Court would not fine Woollfolk any thing. The court however was obliged to fine him something, and they fined him one dollar and costs !'' pRTEn
